target_text: The speaker of parliament grants the speeches in question. Members of Parliament and ministers as well as the Chancellor of Justice can use a speech at plenary session.
The purpose of a joint list is to improve the success rate in elections for candidates from constituencies associations.

The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) is a regional organization that deals with security, whose main areas of activity are arms control and disarmament, democracy, human rights and environmental safety. The members of the OSCE include all European countries as well as Canada, United States and some Central Asian states. The Parliamentary Assembly was established by the Paris Declaration in 1990 along with other institutions within the framework of ETYJ. Members to represent their parliaments are elected from among MPs. The predecessor organization for security cooperation between Europe (OSCE) were held since 1975's Helsinki Summit meetings, which is also known as the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE).
The Committee's Report contains justifications and a proposal for decisions.

The parliamentary reply contains the text of an Act in its form approved by Parliament and any resolutions or notifications on rejecting a government proposal related to it, as well as notification concerning approval or denunciation of international obligations.
A member of parliament may not be prosecuted or arrested for the opinions expressed in Parliament and other actions unless a five-sixths majority has given their consent.
The paragraphs of a subsection are numbered. If there is only one subsection in the article, its paragraphs will be called items (sub-sections).

Announcements include e.g., government proposals submitted to Parliament and the Grand Committee’s agenda for plenary sessions as well as answers to written questions from high ranking guests of a plenary session or schedules on parliamentary work.
The travel and accommodation allowance is intended for the costs incurred in connection with performing a member’s responsibilities as an MP, depending upon their place of residence.

The reservation statement by the Grand Committee obliges the Government to reserve a sufficient time for parliamentary consideration of an issue. The government may make such reservations in EU Council proceedings that state its position will be expressed only after domestic decision-making has been completed, when all language versions have become available or following parliament's constitutional review (parliamentary reservation).

Registration in the Party Register requires that a society has at least 5000 eligible voters as members and adheres to internal decision-making based on member democracy. It must also have rules expressing its goals, such as an overall programme

A member of the committee who is absent from a meeting shall be replaced by an alternate first and foremost in his or her own parliamentary group. If there are several alternates available for this purpose, they will take turns according to their order on the electoral list if no other rule applies.
Elections held in the plenary are defined by the Constitution Act and Parliament’s Rules of Procedure as well as Parliamentary Election Rules.
The entry into force requires the publication of a law. When President has signed it is published in the Statute Book of Finland.
The most important task of a legislature is to exercise its legislative powers.
The information on a Member’s interests are public knowledge.
The Government must submit a report when asked to do so by a parliamentary committee or may also present one of its own initiative.

The Research Service for Members and Other Employees of Parliament provides information services to MPs and other employees at the Finnish parliament. It acquires background material, data sources and online resources, carries out media monitoring as well as trains in using web sources.

The amendment proposal and the counterproposal are put to a vote against each other in turn, after which they go head-to-head with one another until there is only one left standing at the end of it all. The final voting will be on whether or not you support the report as well (yes) - if so then that means you've voted for both proposals and thus supported them too!

A Member of Parliament may request a speaking turn in an issue to be discussed at the plenary session either before or during it from central office, by pressing the speech button on their desk unit. A speaking turn can also be requested in writing with a name tag handed over to the clerk for that purpose and verbally standing up next to one's own seat. Group speeches are reserved through parliamentary group offices. Members of Parliament usually get an opportunity to speak according to order of reservation, but if there is no time left at all or it would take too long before everyone has had a chance to say something on the matter under discussion in question then the Speaker may decide otherwise and give some people more speaking turns than others depending upon what they have said.

The report on the application of language legislation is prepared by the Ministry of Justice in Finland. The report will be discussed at a government meeting but it does not form part of parliamentary documents.

In connection with the budget proposal for state finances, the government submits to parliament legislative proposals that affect revenue accruing to the State or bind appropriations in a statutory purpose. For example, the Act on Social and Health Care Service Charges as well as the Child Benefit Act are typical budget acts.

The Finnish Parliament elects the members of the board for five years at a time from among its own members. Some are elected by the Prime Minister's Office and Ministry for Foreign Affairs, Academy of Finland, rectors' conference in universities as well as Foundation for Research on International Relations (FIIA).
The speakers from Nordic countries and EU member states meet regularly as well as meetings with female speakers are held on a regular basis

The Baltic Sea Parliamentary Conference is an inter-parliamentary cooperation body between the national parliaments of countries around the Baltic Sea. The aim of this conference established in 1991 was to strengthen a common identity and promote governmental co-operation among these states. In addition to representatives from national parliaments, regional parliaments such as the Parliament of Karelia or Schleswig-Holstein State Parliament are also represented at BSPC meetings together with regional organisations like Nordic Council
The Constitution contains basic provisions on matters such as state order and relations between the highest government bodies in addition to fundamental rights.

The Government and each Minister must enjoy the trust of Parliament. If Parliament has passed a motion of censure against it or him/her, the President shall grant his/her resignation to the Government or Minister concerned.
The accounting firm takes care of tasks related to the budget and bookkeeping as well as payment traffic for Parliament's Office of the Parliamentary Ombudsman among other things.

In parliamentary elections parties and constituency associations determine the order of their candidates in a candidate list or joint list themselves. In an election to be held by plenary session at Parliament votes are cast for whole lists rather than individual candidates.

Legislative provisions of a state agreement and other international obligations are brought into force by an Act. Other parts of the international agreements may be entered into force either through a Presidential Decree or Government Decree if it is about European Union treaty
An exception law can only make limited exceptions to the Constitution for compelling reasons (the principle of avoiding exceptional laws)

The Arctic Parliamentary Conference is attended by the legislatures of Finland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Russia, Canada and United States as well as European Parliament and key indigenous organizations in the region. The first conference was held in 1993. The aim of cooperation in the Arctic area is to improve living conditions for people who live there and their status. Key issues include environmental protection, climate change, social questions, position of indigenous peoples and cultural and scientific collaboration.

The Presidency has various tasks related to the management of parliamentary work and it also grants travel authorisations for committees and MPs as well as appoints Parliament’s Remuneration Committee.
Presentation speeches are granted before other speeches.

A supplementary budget is processed together with a state budget and its decision-making procedure is the same as that of the state's annual budget proposal. A complementary amendment to an additional budget may also be presented during consideration of such an addition, i.e., in connection with the presentation of a supplementary draft for it (the so-called supplement).

The Information and Communications Unit is responsible for the library services of Parliament, its internal research service and parliamentary information activities. The Information and Communications Unit includes the Parliamentary Library, Internal Research Service and Parliamentary Information Office. The head of the unit is a Director General in charge of Communication and Information Services
A legislative proposal may concern the enactment or amendment and repeal of an existing law.

A bill concerning the Constitution may be adopted in its first, second reading to rest for over a general election with an absolute majority of votes. After elections it must then be approved without amendment on one and only occasion by two thirds’majority
The Finnish Statute Book's Treaty Series is available online.

The government's legislative proposals are prepared in the ministry whose area of responsibility it is and then approved by the Government plenary session before being presented to the President for submission to Parliament.
The parliamentary power balance can be examined for example on a right-left axis or by group of groups.

The office operates under the Office Commission and is headed by Secretary-General of Parliament. The Parliamentary Office includes Central Office, Committee Secretariat, Administrative Department, International Affairs Unit, Information and Communication Unit as well as Security Division.

The Parliamentary Ombudsman may also submit a special report to Parliament on an issue that he or she considers important, and in connection with the report make proposals for remedying shortcomings of legislation.
The amount of representative compensation decides on Parliament's Remuneration Committee.

A carryover appropriation may be transferred wholly or partly from one financial year to another. A carryover appropriation differs from the annual principle of budgeting in which a state budget applies for only one fiscal year at a time.
A dissenting opinion must be based on the position that has been expressed by a Committee Member during the decisive handling.
There are two galleries in the audience area: lower and upper gallery.
Governments are called after their prime minister's name e.g. Vanhanen II Government.
A committee's report is laid down in some subsequent plenary sitting to be dealt with as a whole for which it has been given.
The term of office for an ad hoc committee continues until it has completed its task.
The basis for processing a draft law usually consists in an opinion by a parliamentary committee.
The activities of the National Audit Office are led by its Director General who is appointed for a term of six years at a time. The appointment to this position requires approval from Parliament.

Originally only used by MPs, the reading room is located in the north wing of Parliament House at ground floor level. The newspaper can be read there including all domestic and most important foreign newspapers.
The Convention is composed of representatives from national parliaments and the heads of state or governments in Member States as well as members of the European Parliament and Commission.

In plenary session, the Speaker of Parliament makes a proposal for voting order. After approval by the House on this matter has been obtained from the speaker, he or she will make such an announcement that indicates how many members voted in favour and against each amendment to be put forward as part of it. The amendments are then placed one after another with their opponents facing them off; if there is a tie between two proposals they remain together until all have had this opportunity for debate before the final vote on both the report (yes) and its opponent, which will decide whether or not an amendment has been adopted by Parliament as part of it.
The state day church services are usually held in Helsinki Cathedral.
In Finland, a result of relative elections are calculated by means of the d'Hondt method.

The term refers to the unofficial cooperation body for a party's ministers represented in Government, and its meetings are used as an opportunity to agree on how they should act when matters come up at State Council level.
The Speaker’s Council in the Parliament appoints a Finnish delegation for an electoral period. The delegation consists of five MPs.

The Swedish Language Office translates the reports and statements of committees into Swedish. The basis for this in Parliament is a Finnish text (the original document). The office also translates other documents related to parliamentary activities from or into Swedish, prepares replies by Parliament that are written in Swedish as well as letters sent out on behalf of Parliament; it arranges interpreting at plenary sessions and committee meetings.

In a supplementary budget it is possible to change the approved expenditure or revenue of the state budget as well as modify either purpose for which appropriations are used in the budget and other justifications given by the government. The preparation process, implementation phase and monitoring phases follow those set out in the action plan concerning the national budget

The Audit Committee deals with matters such as the Government Annual Report submitted to Parliament, a report on its activities by the National Audit Office of Finland and reports from parliamentary auditors' audits. The committee also prepares issues related to control over public finances for consideration in plenary session. The Audit Committee was established in 2007 when it combined tasks relating to state auditing with those performed under the Finance Committee's administrative and audit sub-committee, which is a parliametary supervisory body.

The lawfulness of the actions taken by a State Chancellor is examined on behalf of Parliament, either at least ten MPs have signed an application or if another parliamentary committee has made such request to the Constitutional Law Committee. The Constitutional Law Committee may also examine this issue itself as well. A decision about whether to prosecute will be decided upon in parliament after hearing the position taken by the Constitutional Law Committee on it

Decrees of the ministry contain mainly technical provisions. Until 1 March 2000 when the current Constitution came into force, (1.3.2000), a decree issued by the Ministry was referred to as a decision made by the Ministry. (Ministerial Decree) The abbreviation for an ordinance given by the Ministry includes its letter code and A, e.g., VMA (i.e., Minister of Finance’s Ordinance).

In the detailed examination of a report matter, first decisions are made on sections and resolutions before finally deciding on the grounds for the committee's opinion. In the case of an issue to be considered in detail concerning opinions, it is decided upon that firstly the reasons will be dealt with followed by the resolution matters
The Finnish Parliament has a unicameral system of government.
The expression 'simple proceeding to the agenda' was discontinued on 1 May 2011.

A regular law is taken after the committee reading to two readings in plenary session of Parliament. In first reading, a decision will be made on content and secondly about approval or rejection of an act. A simple majority suffices for approving ordinary laws.
VRTVN's information is a government report on its own initiative or at the request of Parliament.
Filibusters are based on the abuse of a Member's unrestricted speaking rights in Parliament, and have been used most recently when Finland joined the European Union (EU) in 1995.

The Government forms a preliminary common position in an issue to be discussed at the European Union before informing Parliament of Finland and no later than when it is considered by the Grand Committee. The Government's opinion will form based on the determination made by the ministry responsible for the matter. If necessary, different ministries' views are reconciled within the bodies dealing with EU affairs of the Government. In cases where an issue does not come before Parliament's consideration, the government's position represents Finland’s view.
The Speaker’s Council in Parliament appoints Finland’s delegation for the parliamentary term.

A ministerial responsibility case is investigated by the Constitutional Law Committee of Parliament on the basis of a notification made to it either by the Chancellor of Justice or Parliamentary Ombudsman, or based on an admonition signed at least ten MPs. The committee may also investigate such cases in its own initiative. This procedure applies when investigating malfeasance committed by ministers and members of government as well.

Public suffrage means that the right to vote depends only on such conditions as citizens generally have. For example, voting in parliamentary elections requires 18 years of age and Finnish citizenship. Equal suffrage refers to each voter having an equal opportunity to influence election results i.e., one has a single number of votes.

The Speaker's Council prepares a list on the first state days in an electoral term of bills that were passed to rest during the previous parliamentary term, usually including proposals for sending them into committees.
In a continued first reading, it will be based on the report by the Grand Committee.

The first plenary speech is held on a prime minister's announcement, and in the case of an electoral term for which this will be replaced by debate based on government statement about new government's programme.

The lawfulness of the actions taken by an ombudsman is investigated by Parliament's Constitutional Law Committee on a petition signed at least ten MPs or based on another committee's request for investigation, and also in its own initiative. The decision to prosecute shall be made by Parliament after hearing the opinion given by the Constitutional Law Committee concerning this matter.

The Council of Europe is the oldest and largest political cooperation organisation in Europe. It was founded in 1949. Finland joined as a member country in 1989. The most important bodies within the organization are the Committee of Ministers and Parliamentary Assembly consisting of members from national parliaments. The parliamentary assembly makes proposals for decisions which will be made by the committee of ministers on these issues: human rights, legal cooperation, education-, culture -and science collaboration as well as social welfare matters including environmental protection.

In defining the areas of responsibility for special committees, a principle has been followed that corresponds to ministries as far as possible. For example, the Social Affairs and Health Committee handles most matters relating to social affairs and health in accordance with the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health Act, while the Education and Culture Committee deals with issues under its jurisdiction according to the Ministry of Education and Culture Act.

The Office Commission consists of the Speaker and Deputy Speakers as well as four MPs elected by their fellow Members from among themselves to serve on it for a term. The office commission decides e.g., upon Parliament's annual budget proposal; appoints key officials in Parliament, agrees with them about terms of service, uses parliamentary premises and makes significant purchases.
A proposed rejection can be included in a statement by an MP or dissenting opinion of the committee report.
The minutes are public when they have been signed by the Secretary-General of Parliament.

The Finnish Parliament elects members to the Supervisory Board of Yle for each parliamentary term. The Supervisory Board submits an annual report on public service in broadcasting activities to the Finnish Parliament.

The Finnish Parliament elects nine members of the Bank Supervisory Board for each parliamentary term, and they submit an annual report to parliament as well as special reports when necessary. The Parliamentary Bank Supervisory Board also serves on Sitra's Administrative Council.
The parliamentary groups meet on Thursdays.
A constituency association can be established by at least 100 voters who are from the same electoral district as a candidate.

The extension of the Parliament House completed in 1978 consists of A-, B- and C- buildings designed by architects Pitkänen-Laiho-Raunio. The A-and B-buildings have offices for MPs and assistants as well as an auditorium, a room to receive delegations and meeting rooms. In the curved C-building there are office spaces and the Library of Parliament.

A committee may request a statement from another committee of its own initiative. The reporting committee must ask the Constitutional Law Committee for an opinion if there is any doubt about whether or not it concerns constitutional law and human rights treaties in question.

When a treaty or other international obligation contains provisions that fall within the legislative area of ​​Finland's legislation, they are brought into force by an Act approved by Parliament. Otherwise, international obligations will be entered into force through Presidential Decree or if it is about European Union treaties, Government Decrees. The entry-into-force law may take on a form such as blanket act , mixed entry-into-force law and substantive entry-into-force law .
The Ombudsman decides on the division of duties between the Ombudsman and deputy ombudsmen after consulting with them.
The Finnish Parliament has 200 members who are elected for four years at a time.
The reception area is intended to be used by e.g., citizen missions and members of parliament, among others. It can be found in the A-Building.
The Finnish Parliament elects the Council of State Guarantee Fund every parliamentary term. The council consists of nine members.

The expression 'outside the order of business' was abolished on 1 May 2011. It used to refer in plenary sessions before that date to matters which were dealt with separately from other items regularly discussed there, such as interpellations (motions for censure), reports by government and statements made by a prime minister or ministers. The term 'order of business' did not mean the agenda set out at each sitting but rather referred only to plenary sessions in general.

The closing ceremony for the parliamentary term is held in the plenary hall of Parliament where the Speaker addresses a greeting to the President on behalf of the House and the President declares that work by parliament has ended.
In Finland, Parliament exercises its legislative powers. In certain matters the Åland Provincial Council has a right to pass laws for the province of Åland.
The answer to a written parliamentary question must be given in both Finnish and Swedish within 21 days of the date it was received by the Prime Minister’s Office.

The COSAC conference established in 1989 is an association of the committees on European affairs and community matters (COSAC) of national parliaments with competence to issue statements for Union institutions, especially regarding compliance with subsidiarity principles. The Conference meets once during each EU Presidency period i.e., twice a year. It is organised by the Committee on European Affairs in Parliament from the country holding the presidency.
The Prime Minister’s Announcement cannot be sent to a Committee for consideration and no decision will be made on it.
The Bank of Finland operates within the European Systemic Risk Board and in performing its tasks it acts according to guidelines issued by the ECB.

The preamble indicates whether a new law is being enacted or an existing one amended. When the latter occurs, it specifies which parts of the act are to be changed and also states if this has been done in accordance with the procedure for constitutional enactment.

A charge against a member of the Government is heard in the High Court for Impeachment and its initiation requires that Parliament has received an opinion from the Constitutional Law Committee on whether or not there was any violation of law. The same procedure applies to charges brought before the Supreme Chancellor, who also acts as Parliamentary Ombudsman.

The purpose of the International Affairs Forum is to develop parliamentary delegations and committees’ international work as well as identify Finland’s key themes in an international context. The forum was established in 2006 and its members include the Presidency, chairpersons of committees, chairs of Finnish delegations appointed by Parliament or the Speaker's Office, and representatives from the Ministry for Foreign Affairs management team.
The poll clerk appoints the polling assistants. The voters may also use an assistant of their own choosing to help them make a voting mark.

The Finnish Parliament considers proposals for acts and other measures that are to be decided on in the European Union but which under Article 94 of the Constitution would fall within its competence if Finland were not a member state, as well as matters concerning EU legislation or financial issues. The Government submits these U-matters (U = United) with an U-kirjelmä for consideration by Parliament.

The Commerce Committee handles matters relating to trade and industry as well as energy economy, business activities, competition, consumer protection, banking and financial institutions, private insurance operations, the capital market and Bank of Finland.
The Development Co-operation Report is not discussed in the Government and it will be attached to Parliamentary Documents.

The last Parliamentary Auditors' Report was given in 2006. From 1 January 2007 to 2011, Parliament's Audit Committee is responsible for monitoring the management of state finances and compliance with the budget law (the State Budget).
The Speaker's Council in the Finnish Parliament appoints a delegation for Finland during an electoral period. The delegation consists of four members.

The purpose of an electoral alliance is to improve the success in elections for parties that are part of it. The candidates' comparative indices from all participating parties will be calculated by adding their total number of votes together.

The Committee Secretariat's European Union Office coordinates the Finnish Parliament’s activities in and contacts with the institutions of the European Union. The office is formed by officials from both Grand Committees as well as a special adviser working at the parliament building in Brussels, together with an information officer responsible for EU communication

The position of Finland in European Union matters is defined by the Government for which Parliament’s opinion serves as an instructive starting point to ensure that there will be a unified and consistent Finnish view on all issues pending before the EU, at each stage.

The Speaker of Parliament convenes a Plenary Session in accordance with the plenary session schedule as far as possible. The Plenary Session is announced at the end of the previous one, in the Eduskunta building and newspapers. A summons to attend the Plenary Session sounds from the summer house when it begins.

The house built between 1926 and 1931 was designed by J. S. Siren. The building has, for example, a plenary hall as well as meeting rooms and offices. The street address of the Parliament House is Mannerheimintie 30.
The Speaker convenes Plenary Sessions and introduces matters to them in addition to leading discussions at those sessions.

The Social Affairs and Health Committee deals with issues such as social welfare and health care services, social insurance, fees for the provision of social welfare and healthcare services, pension legislation and environmental health.

In Finland there is no actual vote threshold system but it has been said that the hidden vote threshold refers to a percentage of votes cast in an electoral district which must be obtained by at least one candidate from each party or other group. The higher this figure becomes, the more seats are elected for any given constituency and vice versa.
The Statute Book of Finland can be accessed online in general.
A paragraph may contain one or more items (sub-sections).

In matters concerning the European Union, Parliament’s position is formed in the Grand Committee to which usually one or more special committees give a statement of opinion. However, issues relating to common foreign and security policy are handled by the Foreign Affairs Committee.
If at first reading plenary session does not approve the bill as it has been presented in the report prepared for them by committee, then matter is sent back into Grand Committee which prepares its own report on this basis after that issue goes through continued first reading procedure. Bill can also be decided to send out of plenary debate and discussion directly into grand committee during first reading stage
The vote distribution table also indicates those present after a machine-based roll call.

Experts can be heard either by inviting them to a hearing in the committee or asking for an expert statement from them. Officials who have prepared the matter and representatives of agencies, organisations and other bodies that are affected will often be invited as experts. Independent expert parties such as researchers may also be called on.

The aim of the groups is to influence certain international issues. The groups include Parliament's Human Rights Group, Habitat Group, Global Ethics Group, Population Group and PGA (Parliamentarians for Global Action)

The records office prepares the minutes of plenary sessions in which speeches and reports on matters are recorded during a session. The record is drawn up while sitting at parliament's website after it has ended as well as later published by the Parliamentary Documents series.

When sending a matter to the committee for preparation, plenary may decide that certain committees must give an opinion to reporting committee. In European Union matters, Speaker decides which committee gives an opinion on grand committee or foreign affairs committee. Furthermore, Committee can itself request an opinion from another committee.

The Speaker convenes the plenary sessions and presents matters to them as well as leads discussions in them. The issues decided on at a plenary session are usually prepared by committees before that, unless otherwise provided for in Parliament’s Rules of Procedure or other legislation. Plenary sittings are public meetings.
The Speaker’s Council decides to hold a part of the discussion as a fast-track debate and on its speaking time.

An Act may enter into force at the earliest when it has been published in the Official Gazette of Finland . For a special reason , an Act can provide that its entry into force is to be provided for by decree.

The Administrative Office takes care of matters related to human resources and training such as personnel administration and services provided by the agency; occupational safety and health protection at work and occupational healthcare

If the person who issues an act is not provided for separately in law, it shall be issued by Government. Until 1 March 2000 when current Constitution came into force a decision of Council was used to refer to acts given by that body before this date.

A member of parliament has the right to submit legislative motions (law proposals), budgetary motions and supplementary budgetary motions as well as petitionary motions. Only when Parliament is in session may a parliamentary motion be submitted by an MP.

Acts are divided into sections that may be further subdivided into items and the latter in turn to paragraphs, which can then form chapters or parts of larger acts. A section may contain one or more provisions.
The Committee may give its opinion to the Finance Committee within thirty days of receiving a copy if it so wishes.

A member of a committee is elected in addition to members and substitutes for the absence from work due to illness or other reasons. If an ordinary member cannot participate in the activities of the Committee must notify his substitute so that he can attend on their behalf at meetings of the Committee, if necessary. A substitute may follow even when full attendance by a committee meeting but they are not entitled to take part in decision-making during such time.

In an open-ballot vote the ballot papers indicate the name of each voter. In a closed-ballot vote, i.e., voting with sealed ballots, (ballot paper in secret), it is not possible to identify who voted after casting their votes. A closed-ballot election (secret ballot) is usually used for elections involving officials or other positions that require secrecy and discretion.
At the end of an electoral period most matters that have not been completed in Parliament will lapse.

The parliamentary term is divided into sessions and the Parliament convenes for a session annually usually in early February, which continues until it reconvenes at the beginning of its next term. The spring and autumn sittings are held during each session.

The office of the special adviser to Parliament in Brussels was established in 1996, and since 1 January 1997 it has been located within the Committee Secretariat's European Union Secretariat . The special advisor represents Parliament at EU institutions. He also prepares reports for all MPs on current issues that are available to them as well as other officials.

In parliamentary elections the final result is confirmed by constituency election committees. In presidential and European Parliament elections it is done in Helsinki Electoral Committee while for municipal elections this task belongs to central electoral committee of municipality.

The Secretary of Parliament is the Parliamentary Secretary-General. The tasks of the parliamentary secretary include signing with the Speaker of Parliament answers and letters from parliament, checking and approving summary records (decision protocols) for plenary sessions as well as candidate lists in elections to bodies within parliament; he or she also leads and supervises activities at the Office of Parliament.

The minutes of the committee are recorded in a record that lists members present at meetings and experts heard by them as well as proposals made to it, votes taken on its decisions or documents received from it for consideration during proceedings which have been prepared either directly by itself’s secretary.

In a committee the result of voting is determined by lot if there are an equal number of votes cast in favour and against it. In cases where criminal liability under consideration before the Constitutional Law Committee cannot be resolved on grounds that both sides have equally strong arguments, the more lenient view prevails. If no decision can be reached at a plenary session through open-ballot voting due to an equal division between those who are for or opposed in votes cast by members of parliament present and entitled to vote, lot determines which side wins out.
The sections are divided into four major types in the revenue estimate: (1) taxes and tax-like revenues, (2) miscellaneous income, (3) interest incomes and profit distributions as well as (4) loans.

The Government must reply to the interpellation in plenary session within fifteen days. After receiving a response from the government on an interpellation, Parliament will hold discussions and vote at its end of whether or not it has confidence in the cabinet or minister concerned.

The Parliament elects for each parliamentary term twelve deputies and one deputy to the Social Insurance Institution (Kela). The deputies give an annual report on their activities before the Parliament.

If the bill is adopted in detailed consideration as proposed by a committee report, (1), it proceeds to second reading. Otherwise, the matter will be referred back for further first-reading debate (continued) with an opinion from the Grand Committee on which basis matters are considered at continued first reading. (1). The budget also undergoes detailed discussion after general discussion and if amendments differing in detail from those proposed by a committee report of the Finance Committee were adopted, it would be referred back to that committee.
The comments are held from their seats and usually last no more than a minute each.
The Parliament elects five auditors and one deputy auditor for the Bank of Finland every year.

Parliamentary documents are published in the Parliamentary Documents series and on Parliament’s website. The Parliamentary Documents series publishes e.g. parliamentary motions by members of parliament (MPs), minutes from plenary sessions as well as their Swedish summaries, government proposals, communications issued by the Government to Parliament, notices and reports submitted for consideration by a committee or other body in charge with preparing legislation, replies given on behalf of MPs, interpellations made against ministers’ actions and written questions together with answers.

The Government or the Ministry must provide a report to the Foreign Affairs Committee on preparation of matters concerning foreign and security policy in the European Union, as well as other issues for which it has been requested by committees; The government may also submit its own initiative.
The Speaker's Council in the Parliament appoints a Finnish delegation for an electoral period. The delegation includes three MPs as members and three as deputies.
The term refers to actions taken by a Member of Parliament during the Parliamentary session.

There are two ways to enact a constitution and an exceptive act: 1) The bill is first passed in the second reading with simple majority for one year. After that it must be approved without any changes by two-thirds of all members present at least three times during its final passage, which may not take place earlier than six months after the beginning of this period or later than two years from then on. 2) The bill is declared urgent in a second reading with five-sixths majority and passed thereafter also by simple majority.

The Committee on Future Affairs deals with factors affecting development in the future and research into futures as well as technological developments' effects. The Committee does not usually deal with bills of law.
The question will be addressed to that Minister whose area of responsibility it concerns. The duration of a question and its answer may not exceed one minute.

An Act approved by the Parliament is presented to the President of Finland for ratification. If the President does not approve it, then an act returns to parliament and becomes valid without being confirmed if accepted again unchanged in its substance. In Finnish general language (and partly also legal) law refers both to existing laws as well as a system of justice
The Parliament Restaurant is located in the south wing of the first floor of the Parliament Building.

Members of Parliament establish friendship groups to complement the official international activities carried out by parliamentarians in Finland’s national legislature (Eduskunta). The aim is for these groups to maintain relations with parliaments from different countries and groupings. They also seek to learn about their cultures, societies and political systems. Friendship groups are particularly important when there is no formal contact between two or more nations.

In accordance with the procedure for constitutional enactment, a bill is adopted in second reading by simple majority to be laid aside until after the next parliamentary elections on days of state that are held following those elections. After these elections have been completed and new parliament has convened, such bills must then still pass through two thirds vote before they can become law. The procedure for constitutional enactment is used when a bill amends or supplements provisions in Finland's Constitution (731/1999).
The result boards in the Plenary Hall show how many people voted for 'Yes' and 'No' or abstained from voting.
For female MPs, three rooms were furnished in the Parliament Building: yellow, red and grey. The Yellow and Red Women's Rooms are now used for other purposes.

In many countries' legislatures there are two chambers of which one is elected by general elections (e.g., in Great Britain the House of Commons and United States Congress) while membership to another chamber can be determined on different grounds (e.g., in Great Britain the House of Lords, Senate). In federations members from this latter house often represent states.
The Election Financing Record publishes the declarations of funding for parliamentary elections, presidential elections, municipal elections and European Parliament elections.
The Legal Affairs Committee deals with legislation on family law and succession rights as well as obligations and property matters; criminal justice systems; courts of law; and the prison service.
The Parliament Cafeteria is located in the southern wing of the Parliamentary Building on the second floor.

For the processing and decision-making in European Union institutions and its preparatory bodies a national position is prepared for Finland. In Finland preparation of this work lies with government but it has to be said that most responsibility rests upon ministries. Government must give information about preparations concerning issues which are decided on within EU, or would fall under Parliament's competence if Finland were not an EU member state. The parliamentary opinion serves as a guideline in the actions taken by the Finnish government regarding European Union matters.

By approving the Act, Parliament gives its consent to Finland’s commitment to a convention or other international obligation. Parliamentary approval is required for such conventions and other international obligations that contain provisions falling within the scope of legislation; affect parliamentary budgetary power; concern changes in state territory or are otherwise significant. Parliamentary approval also applies when terminating an agreement with this kind, accepting reservations relating to it or withdrawing them.

The Speaker’s Council in the Parliament appoints a Finnish delegation for an electoral period. The delegation consists of six MPs. Finland has one representative and one alternate member to the permanent committee at the conference.

Every parliamentary group decides for itself on its rules of voting behaviour. A parliamentary group may give members freedom to vote differently from the group's position or according to their conscience in individual cases.

The master list of candidates is taken in the order drawn up by parties and constituency associations, as well as joint lists to be included into it. The candidate list combination can also be seen at a voting booth among other places.

In parliamentary elections every eligible voter who is not a minor or in military service can stand as candidate for election to the Parliament of Finland. The Chancellor of Justice and Parliamentary Ombudsman cannot be members of parliament without resigning from their offices, nor may any member of either Supreme Court (korkein oikeus) or Administrative Court (korkein hallinto-oikeus), Prosecutor General (valtakunnansyyttäjä) or President of the Republic serve as a Member of Parliament while holding office.

In Finland there is no constitutional court but the determination of constitutionality and supervision thereof are based upon prior control which takes place during parliamentary proceedings concerning laws or other matters. The Constitutional Law Committee supervises whether a bill to be submitted for consideration in Parliament contains provisions that conflict with the Constitution, as well as how such conflicts can best be resolved. The opinion given by the Constitutional Law Committee on constitutionality is binding both before and after plenary sessions of the Finnish parliament.
For example, the Personal Data Act is a general law in relation to laws concerning processing of personal data by police forces and border guards.
The Government Proposal for a State Budget includes general explanations and detailed explanations in addition to its table of contents.

The parliamentary reply or letter includes the statement that has been adopted in Parliament. The Government will report to Parliament at a later date through its annual government action reports and state accounts of what measures it has taken due to this resolution approved by parliament.

The Finnish Parliament meets annually for parliamentary sessions at a time determined by it itself, (usually in early February) and, if necessary, the Speaker of Parliament may summon parliament to meet again before new general elections are held.

The Administrative Department is responsible for administrative matters in the Parliament such as finances, real estate and information technology management personnel administration issues preparation of office commission for . The head of department is the Director General of Administration. There are an administrative office , accounting offices, property services departments and Information Management Office.
Fiscal powers include authority to decide on tax laws and control of state finances.
The Library of Parliament is a public library open to all people and serves the Finnish Parliament as well as acts as its central archive and centre for legal information on society.

The Committee on Employment and Equality deals with issues such as the working environment, occupational safety, health care at work, labour force, employment, equality of opportunity for men and women in society, civil service matters. It also handles questions concerning employees' participation in preparing decisions made by their employer’s management board or equivalent body.

Members can be MPs who are eligible to vote. However, the Chancellor of Justice and Parliamentary Ombudsman cannot become members; neither may a member of Parliament or President nor an officer in military service
Puitedirectives were used, especially in earlier times, to form part of various public planning systems.

The Speaker decides on the order of business and may change it by changing the procedure or adding matters to be dealt with in a supplementary plenary session agenda. (The speaker can also remove items from an agenda.)

If the issuer of an act is not provided for separately in a decree, it shall be issued by the Government Council.
Until 1 March 2000 when Finland's current Constitution came into force, the term 'act' referred to administrative decrees given by the President of the Republic

A Member of Parliament may be prevented from participating in the plenary session due to a parliamentary task or illness related to parliament work; maternity leave, paternity leave and parental leave. (See notice of absence.) A non-mentioned reason for being absent is recorded as other absences.
Budget motions are made and processed in connection with each year's budget proposals.
The Finnish Parliament can decide to suspend its sessions, for example during summer and Christmas breaks. The Speaker may invite it back into a session that has been suspended

The committee reading usually begins with the hearing of experts. After receiving all necessary information for resolving an issue, a committee holds preparatory debate on it and then its secretary prepares draft statement or report from which there is general discussion followed by detailed consideration. If the committee unanimously decides to consider detail as decisive handling in this case otherwise separate decisive dealing will be taken with regard to that matter
The Parliament approves or rejects a Bill in the Second Reading. The approval is reported to the Government by means of Parliamentary Reply

An issue may be taken up for advance reading e.g., due to urgency before it has actually come into the committee's possession. The term 'advance reading' can also be used when a committee is not quorate at its first meeting on an item of business.
In Finland, a Government must enjoy parliamentary confidence.
An officials' election takes place by secret ballot.
The budget statement will be notified to the Government in a Parliamentary Communication.
In each electoral area there is a place of vote for Election Day determined by decision made in the municipal executive board.

The decrees of the President of the Republic mainly concern the entry into force of international obligations or other conventions, and were formerly referred to as regulations under current legislation until 1 March 2000 when it came in effect.

Party subsidies are paid on the basis of parliamentary seats. The distribution and use of party support is decided by the Government Council for Political Affairs (Government), which supervises its implementation in cooperation with the Ministry of Justice.
Legislation is initiated in Parliament by a government proposal or an initiative from the Member of Parliament.

A government proposal may concern e.g., an act or a supplementary state budget of the State Budget Act, Parliament's consent to borrowing by central government and granting guarantees for loans taken out in Finland as well as approving international agreements concluded between states or supplementing previously submitted proposals from the Government.

A legislative proposal may be included in a government bill or member’s motion for legislation submitted by an MP and report of the committee. The term ‘legislative proposals’ should not be used as synonym to “government bills”

Regular meetings of the secretaries-general of parliaments are held, for example between those in Nordic and Baltic countries as well as among members states' parliamentary secretariats within European Union. The meeting of the Association of Secretaries-General of Parliaments (ASGP) is organised at IPU General Assemblies.
The revenue estimates also include loans.

The Finnish Parliament may grant a Member of Parliament an exemption from their duties for good reason at the request made by them. Such reasons include serious illness or holding high office in society and public life.
The organisation of the Finnish Parliament includes choosing members for the Presidency and committees as well as deciding on seating arrangements in plenary hall.
The official appointed Parliamentary Ombudsman works in charge of the Office for Parliamentary Ombudsmen (Office).

The Finnish Parliament approves on a proposal from the Speaker's Council among other things rules of procedure for Parliamentary Ombudsman and Bank Supervisory Board members as well as Social Insurance Institution (Kela) board.
The Social and Health Report will not be discussed by the Government or attached to Parliamentary documents.
The Defence Committee deals with matters relating to conscription and the Finnish Defence Forces, among other things.

The Foreign Affairs Committee considers significant conventions and treaties as well as general foreign policy issues, trade policies abroad, development cooperation matters, international organisations and the deployment of Finnish peacekeeping forces. It also deals with European Union common external security affairs.

For parliamentary elections, the country is divided into constituencies based on regional division (maakuntajako). According to the Constitution Act of Finland, there must be at least twelve and no more than eighteen electoral districts in total.
The pension security for a Member of Parliament includes old-age pension, disability pension and family pension.
In Finland, a member of parliament has an unrestricted speaking rights in the plenary assembly provided that he or she remains within topic boundaries and does not insult another person.

The International Affairs Unit is responsible for international relations and related practical matters in the Finnish Parliament. The unit assists the Speakers of Parliament as well as the Secretary-General with their work concerning parliamentary institutions, committees and other units within parliament except EU-related issues. In addition to this it acts also as a secretariat for Parliamentary Delegations appointed by the Parliament; maintains contacts between parliaments around the world, international organisations’ secretariats and foreign ministries of Finland. The head of International Affairs Unit is its Director

An issue to be decided by the Finnish Parliament is usually dealt with in advance before it can finally be resolved at a plenary session of parliament. For this purpose there are parliamentary committees, i.e., special and grand committees within the committee system
The National Audit Office also submits separate reports to Parliament if necessary.
The task of a Plenary Session Clerk is performed by Parliament's Director for Legislation and Parliamentary Secretaries in the Secretariat.

Y matters came before the Finnish Parliament during Finland's membership of the European Economic Area in 1994. The processing of pending Y issues continued under provisions on U affairs when Finland joined the EU at the beginning of 1995.

The election protocol includes the start and end of polling as well as those present at voting including members of the electoral board and assistants. The number of voters is also recorded along with who was there when counting votes took place and what that result was.
In parliamentary elections candidates may be nominated by parties and constituency associations.
Late sign-in is done in the same way as signing up for a plenary session: by pressing the 'present' button. The MP will be marked present from that moment on.

VRML. The parliamentary communication is used to report on decisions or positions concerning e.g., the state budget, selection of a prime minister, adjournment and termination of parliament sessions as well as convening an assembly session for Parliament; government reports (reports by the Government), approval of motions submitted by members of Parliament and elections in certain bodies within Parliament.

A minister may not hold a public office or any other position that could interfere with the performance of his duties during their term. After being appointed to serve as Minister he must provide Parliament for information on business activities and ownership in companies, significant assets and all other interests such as debts.

A member of parliament must give a report to Parliament on their interests within two months from the date when his or her credentials have been examined by Parliament. These are those tasks outside one's parliamentary duties that may affect one’s ability as an MP and include business activities, ownership in companies and other significant assets which can be considered relevant for assessing how they act while representing others. The information is stored on a register of interests maintained at the Finnish parliament whose contents will become public upon request.
The follow-up letter will be processed like an E-letter and the Grand Committee or Foreign Affairs Committee can revise its position on the E-letter based on it.
The abbreviation of a registered political party in Finnish is rp. (formerly r.p.)
In the case of a simplified procedure, when amending the Constitution requires only two-thirds majority and does not require leaving it to rest over elections.

All the MPs of Parliament are members of the Finnish Group within Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU). At its first annual meeting during each parliamentary term, it elects a board from among itself to serve as chairperson. The Board appoints delegations for IPU General Assemblies.
The attendance statistics for the plenary sessions separate out those representatives' absences due to illness or maternity leave and other reasons.
When a bill has been considered by the Committee of Inquiry in detail it returns to plenary session for first and second reading which consists of general debate followed by consideration in details
In the plenary sitting a vote is conducted using an electronic vote teller or by standing up and casting your ballot paper into it. The Speaker announces how to cast one's votes in this case.

The Auditors of Parliament give the Finnish Parliament two reports on audits: 1. The report by the Auditors of Parliament concerning the financial statements and management accounts as well as administration for the year in question; 2. A separate audit opinion from the National Audit Office, which is a public accounting firm that audits central government agencies
A Member of Parliament can make a proposal for an expression of no confidence during discussion on e.g., the Interpellation or Government Statement Motion

The Speaker of the House selects three members for a four-year term from among those who are not MPs or employees in Parliament to form the Parliamentary Remuneration Committee, which is responsible for determining MPs' salaries and other remunerations.
The street address of Building C is Aurora Street 6.

The second reading is held at the earliest on the third day after the end of the first reading, and it cannot be used to change any part of a law anymore. In this stage, Parliament also decides whether or not there are resolutions in connection with an issue that should be approved by parliament. The decision made about approving or rejecting a bill is reported back to government through parliamentary reply.
The Parliament Auditorium of Finland's Eduskunta (Parliament) building can be found in Building A.

The committee secretariat is responsible for preparing the reports and statements of committees, as well as ensuring that meetings are prepared in advance and meeting minutes are drawn up. The staff members working at the committee secretariat consist of officials from both the grand committee and special public bill committees. The deputy secretary-general acts as head of the committee secretariat.
The preparation of laws and decrees as well as legal rules issued by authorities is called statutory drafting.
The Visitor's Centre has a meeting and lecture room for about 50 people, along with an audience café.

The NATO Parliamentary Assembly is a forum for cooperation between the parliaments of member states, which serves as an arena to discuss security policy issues and acts in close collaboration with NATO but has no formal connection with it. The members are all countries that have joined NATO; there also exist associate memberships or observers who can participate without voting rights. The Finnish Parliament is a non-permanent observer since 1998.

A Member of Parliament may choose a personal assistant to assist him or her in parliamentary activities and tasks related thereto; the task is also to maintain contact with the MP's interest groups, gather background material for his or her parliamentary actions and keep track of them. The assistant works under an employment contract between the Parliamentary Office and the National Assembly.

Finland has five members and five deputy members of parliament elected by the Finnish Parliament in its entirety to represent Finland at the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE). The delegation is appointed for a parliamentary term, which begins with the first session after general elections. Each year it submits an annual report on activities carried out during that period to the plenary sitting of parliament.
The speeches are granted by Speaker of Parliament.

In parliamentary elections candidates may be nominated by parties and constituency associations. They submit their candidate lists to the constituency electoral committee which examines whether they are eligible as a candidate and confirms nomination of candidates.

The members of parliament sit in the plenary hall according to parliamentary groups so that left-wing parties are on the left, middle parties in the centre and right-wing parties on the right side from the speaker's perspective. The Speaker Council makes proposals for group seating arrangements within Parliament. Parliamentary groups decide themselves about places inside their own groups. Usually those who have been members of parliament longest sit at the front.
A commencement provision usually appears at the end of a statute.

Members of Parliament are elected by direct, proportional and secret elections. In the direct election a voter votes directly for their own candidate. In the proportional vote each group gets as many representatives in proportion to its number of votes compared with other groups’ numbers of votes. The secret ballot means that only the voter knows who they have voted for.

The Parliament elects the Library Board for each parliamentary term from among its members and three persons outside of it as well as one staff representative with a deputy member to serve on the board annually, which submits an annual report about library activities to parliament
A Member of Parliament registers their presence by pressing a 'present' button.
In statutes, legal norms are called provisions.

The Committee on Agriculture and Forestry handles issues such as agriculture and forestry, rural industries, veterinary medicine, animal welfare, food hygiene, hunting, fishing, reindeer husbandry, land surveying, cadastre and geodetic research.
The notice includes the date and place for advance voting as well as contact information of officials in charge at polling stations.

The legislative body of Åland is the Provincial Council which enacts provincial acts and appoints the Government of the Province of Åland. The provisions concerning self-government are included in the Act on Self-Government for the Åland Islands, which can only be amended by a joint decision from both Parliament and the Provincial Council.
The term convention can also be used in a narrower sense to refer only to international agreements that are legally binding between states.

The Regional State Administrative Agency appoints the members of constituency electoral committees from parties that have fielded candidates in previous parliamentary elections for this electoral district. The constituency electoral committee counts advance votes cast and carries out a recount on election day’s ballots within its own electoral district.
The Government of Finland (Finnish: Suomen hallitus) refers to a group that exercises executive power in Finland and consists of one or more ministers who are appointed by the President.

The expression 'proposal for the wording of a motion to proceed out of order' was discontinued on 1 May 2011. 'Outside the Order Paper' were discussed interpellations (motion of censure), government reports and statements by the Prime Minister as well as motions relating to them, which could be made during debate after their conclusion in plenary session. If there had been a proposal for a motion that justified proceeding out of order it was put up against an alternative proposition on what wording should have been used when moving from one item to another and then voted upon by the House.
A Member of Parliament has the right to submit legislative motions and budgetary motions.
A Member of Parliament submits an announcement to the Central Office about their absence from a Plenary Session when they are absent due to parliamentary work or illness.

A sub-committee can be set up by a committee to prepare the matter under consideration and draft an opinion or report for it, which is then submitted as such to its plenary session. Permanent subcommittees exist in both the Grand Committee (the largest parliamentary committee) and the Finance Committee.
Many acts have an official title and a shorter unofficial nickname such as Act of Public Honors which is also known by the short name Honours Act
The Finance Committee handles matters such as the Budget Proposals and Supplementary Budget Proposals of state finances, tax laws and issues concerning government borrowing.

After the parliamentary elections, the parliamentary groups negotiate on a government programme and composition of the Government Council (cabinet). The negotiations are usually led by the chairman of the party that received most votes in the election. Based on results from these talks President gives information to Parliament about Prime Minister candidate. Candidate is elected as prime minister if he or she gets more than half given vote at parliament. Other ministers president appoints according proposal made by PM.

Parliamentary business to be discussed in plenary includes e.g. government proposals and parliamentary motions by members of parliament as well as oral questions and interpellations (censure motion). In addition, parliamentary matters include written questions and European Union issues handled within committees.

After the elections MPs elected from a single candidate list form an parliamentary group. Being part of such a group is voluntary and it can decide who to accept as its member. Parliamentary groups play an important role in both parliament work and political party activities.

The Finnish Parliament is unicameral. It has 200 members who are elected for a term of four years at the same time in direct and secret elections by proportional representation.
The parliament enacts laws, decides on Finland's state budget, approves most important international treaties and supervises government activities.
The term refers to how many parliaments a Member has participated in by the term 'parliamentary experience'.
The word Arkadianmäki is sometimes used as a synonym for the Finnish Parliament and its parliamentary house.

The Member States of the European Union have transferred their powers in matters defined by EU treaties to institutions at a European level, such as agriculture and trade policy (e.g.). Some legislative power previously exercised independently has also been transferred from Finland's national government to the EU.

The position of the Finnish Parliament in matters concerning European Union is formed by the Grand Committee to which usually one or more special committees give a statement. However, issues related to common foreign and security policy are dealt with by the Foreign Affairs Committee. The Grand Committee or the Foreign Affairs Committee may issue an opinion that represents the view of parliament on Finland’s negotiating objectives for matters concerning European Union. The position expressed in this manner is only indicative as regards how the Government should act when it comes into contact with other member states and institutions within Europe, but its importance cannot be underestimated.
Cf. simple majority.

Questions asked during the Question Hour usually concern current political issues and are answered by ministers without prior preparation. The oral question hour is held on Thursdays at 4 p.m., as its name suggests it lasts about an hour.

The Inter-Parliamentary Union is the oldest inter-parliamentary cooperation organization in the world and was founded in 1889 as a group of Finnish parliaments 1920. At present IPU members are almost all working parliaments around the globe, with its main objectives being to promote democracy and parliamentarianism worldwide. IPU has observer status at UN headquarters and works closely together with other United Nations agencies such as UNICEF or WHO
The Veps information management system records the reference data of parliamentary business and documents related to it as well as the stages in plenary sessions with voting results.

The president must confirm the law within three months of receiving a parliamentary reply from parliament to it being delivered by government. A bill that has not been confirmed is considered again in plenary session as one reading matter and when committee report on this, then approved or rejected without amendment at issue content.
An amendment may concern e.g., a bill contained in the Committee's Report on Budget Proposal or Resolution

A report to the Committee can be given either at its request or on initiative by the Government, a ministry of state. The committee may give an opinion based on this study for the government and ministries.

The national parliament may submit a reasoned opinion to an institution of the European Union on any draft legislative act that it considers infringes the principle of subsidiarity, according to which EU action in areas not falling within its exclusive competence is only justified where objectives cannot be sufficiently achieved by Member States or their regional and local authorities. In Finland, giving such opinions to a body of the European Union falls under the authority of plenary session on proposal from grand committee. A member of great committee may submit an initiative for consideration in respect of subsidiarity issue before great committee; it can also do so if special committees concerned by matter or Åland provincial council has done that.

The central office is responsible for the preparation and implementation of plenary sessions as well as service tasks related to them. The Central Office takes care of delivering parliamentary documents, translating and publishing them, maintaining registers and distributing these documents. In addition to a secretariat there are an activity unit with assistants in charge, records offices, Swedish language offices and document offices within the central office. The Director General for Legislation is responsible for the work carried out by the Central Office.
The Speaker’s Council decides on holding of group speeches.

A complementary Government Proposal is considered by the Committee together with the original one. A supplementary proposal cannot be submitted after a committee has issued its report in preparation of an issue.
The Speaker may interrupt consideration in a plenary sitting. Consideration will continue at some later plenary sitting.
The basis for the major titles is administrative division and thus there are e.g., Parliament, President of Finland, Government as well as different ministries' administration areas in them.

The Committee may hear experts either by inviting them to appear before the meeting or asking for an expert statement in writing from them. Usually, those who are heard as witnesses submit a written opinion.

A proposed resolution may be included in a report of the committee or it can be made directly to plenary session by an MP. If Parliament approves this proposal for a resolution, then that is taken into account when preparing parliamentary reply and other documents sent out from parliament. The government reports on its actions concerning these resolutions later through annual accounts submitted annually as part of the Government’s Annual Report (Hallituksen toimenpidekertomus) or State Financial Statement (Valtion tilinpäätöskertomus).

The Nordic Council was established in 1952 and Finland joined the council as a member state in 1955. The members of the Nordic Council are Denmark, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Finland and the autonomous regions Åland Islands, Faroe Islands and Greenland. The council can make recommendations to the governments or ministerial councils of the countries involved for facilitating mobility between citizens, companies, goods and capital within the region. The aim is also to facilitate cooperation in other areas such as culture, education, research and social affairs through Nordic co-operation projects funded by the Nordic Council budget.
In insurance, speakers promise to act in accordance with the Constitution and defend the rights of Finland's people and Parliament.
Government proposals and U-Statements are currently distributed in black corner versions.

The Administration Committee handles matters such as central and local government in Finland. It also deals with regional policy, general administration issues, personnel policies of the state sector, police work and rescue services, accident investigation, border guard activities, immigration affairs and municipal and church affairs.

The decision on the approval of a provincial act is delivered to the Ministry of Justice which examines whether or not it falls within the legislative power of the Provincial Council, and if so what part does this fall under? If necessary, the President may order that all or some parts of such an Act lapse.
In accordance with a Speaker Council guideline, speeches should not exceed ten minutes in length.
The parliamentary elections are held every four years and in them the number of MPs is elected to be 200 members. The highest election authority is the Ministry of Justice.
The Employment Report will not be discussed in the Government and attached to Parliamentary Documents.
The size of a parliamentary group's offices varies depending on its size.

The proposal for a decision in the report or opinion of the committee may contain one or more resolutions. In its resolution, the Committee can propose to Parliament that it approve, reject or amend an Act and adopt a statement on this matter. The Constitutional Law Committee's resolution usually concerns the order of procedure concerning matters under consideration by the House.
The Education and Culture Committee deals with issues such as upbringing, education, science, art, general cultural activities, sports, youth work, copyright law and student aid.
A new law proposed in the Committee must be related to an existing government proposal or parliamentary initiative.
The municipal council appoints the members of the election committee from those parties that have nominated candidates in previous parliamentary elections for this electoral district.
In general language, the word voter can also be used as a synonym for an eligible voter and supporter of a party.
Voting can be conducted at the home of a voter if it is unreasonable for them to get there due e.g., because they are physically disabled.

Group speeches are held when discussing matters such as the state budget and government statements or reports of the Government (i.e., a report by the Cabinet). The group speakers will be chosen in order from largest to smallest according to their respective parliamentary groups’ sizes.
By a Government Resolution to be submitted for consideration by Parliament are matters concerning the construction of nuclear facilities with general significance.
The expression 'justified proceeding to the agenda' was discontinued on 1 May 2011.

After the preliminary vote count, the number of votes cast for each candidate is recorded in an election record and reported to a central municipal electoral committee. Ballot papers are packaged together with the election records and sealed before being delivered by local elections to a central municipal electoral committee and other general elections to constituency electoral committees.

Party subsidies are not considered to be party support, such as a state subsidy or other similar assistance based on law and the budget of either central government or local authorities. Support is also excluded from e.g., volunteer work for parties, income generated by investment activities carried out in accordance with market conditions (e.g., shares) or business operations conducted according to commercial principles

A Member of Parliament can be removed from office for a fixed period or permanently due to neglecting their duties as an MP. The Finnish Parliament may decide that the representative’s position is terminated if they have been sentenced by court to imprisonment on account of a deliberate crime, or punished in some other way because of election-related crimes. These decisions are made with two thirds majority vote at the Eduskunta.

The purpose of the preliminary debate is to provide guidance for a committee in its preparatory work on an issue. During this discussion no decisions are made about matters such as content or scope of legislation. After the preliminary debate has taken place and following proposals by the Speaker’s Council, plenary session decides which committees will deal with each matter referred to them.

The President of the Supreme Court serves as Chairman and other members are the Presidents of the highest administrative court, three oldest presidents of district courts and five Members elected by Parliament for a term of four years each with one deputy member per Member. The High Impeachment Court convenes when necessary.
The Finnish Parliament elects two Deputy Speakers from among its members who alternate with the Speaker in leading a plenary sitting.

During the general discussion in plenary session, it may decide to send a matter into Grand Committee for further consideration. The proceedings are then based on report of grand committee.
Also state budget is discussed before detailed examination according to finance committee’s report
In legislative matters the right to introduce a motion in Parliament is held by government ministers and MPs as well as the Speaker’s Council.

A draft report or statement is discussed in a committee and considered in detail on the basis of it, either unanimously by the members present at that meeting to decide whether this will be decisive consideration for them as regards their position concerning an issue; otherwise there may also take place separate decisive consideration.

The Western European Union is a security and defence policy cooperation organisation in Europe that was established as the Parliamentary Assembly of WEU 1955. In addition to members states of WEU there are associate member countries and partners, along with observer nations including the Finnish Parliament which has been participating since 1995.
In a voting booth, there will be an election manifesto for display.
The plenary hall's circular desk was previously used by shorthand writers.
If a Member of Parliament has not reached the retirement age at the end of their term in office they are entitled to an adjustment allowance for one or three years depending upon how long it was.
A two-thirds majority is required for example to pass the law on amending the Constitution or to expel an MP from office due to neglect of duties as a representative.
Vote on confidence is a vote in which members cast their votes for or against the proposal to express no-confidence towards government and its actions (e.g., motion of censure).

If a Member of Parliament dies during the parliamentary term, he or she is granted leave to be absent from his or her duties as an MP for life.
