If they are elected Members of European Parliament (MEPs), their seat in parliament will become vacant and it may either remain so until the end of that parliamentary term or only temporarily if a replacement member has been appointed by the party group concerned, who is then entitled to serve out his or her predecessor's remaining period as an MP.

The Government must reply to an interpellation in the plenary session of Parliament within 15 days from receiving notice thereof. Usually it is that Minister whose area of responsibility a question concerns who replies thereto. After having received this answer on its interpellation, Parliament has debate thereon and then votes whether or not confidence should be placed upon the Government as such and/or any particular member(s) thereof.
The Speaker may allow follow-up questions to be asked.

The consideration of an interpellation and a government statement is not continued on the following parliamentary term in Finland’s Parliament. The consideration of a report by the Government continues if so decided upon during the next parliamentary term, provided that it has been submitted to parliament for discussion before its dissolution. If necessary, international matters may also be considered after the general elections held between two parliamentary terms.
The Deputy Speaker also has a special assistant.
The voting agent has a right to be present at vote counting.

The Rules of Procedure of the Parliament are a statutory instrument that is exclusively in the decision making power of the parliament and which will be adopted by plenary session under ordinary law procedure. It does not need to receive presidential approval.

In the 1980s, the building designed by Hilding Ekelund for the Finnish City Association was purchased to serve as a working and meeting room of Parliament House. The street address is Eduskuntakatu 4.

The Committee for Transport and Communications handles matters relating to road transport, railways, air traffic, inland waterway navigation, shipping, postal services, telecommunications, broadcasting as well as other communications.
A Government Statement is given on matters such as a Government Programme. Compare with a Government Report (Report).
The person working in the officials' box is, among others, an interpreter of a plenary sitting and updater of the Plenary Hall Information System

The Security Department of Parliament is responsible for the functionality and development of the safety system in Parliament as well as its rescue operations and civil defence activities. The Director General of the Security Unit heads it.
The MP’s right to access does not apply to confidential data or the state budget draft.
In parliamentary elections every Finnish citizen who has reached the age of eighteen by the polling date is entitled to vote.
The municipal council appoints the members of the election committee from those parties that have nominated candidates in previous parliamentary elections for this electoral region.
The Environment Committee handles matters relating to housing and planning as well as environmental protection, waste management and water legislation among other things.

In advance polling stations such as municipal offices or post offices and Finnish embassies abroad any eligible voter can vote. In special advance polling places only certain persons may cast their votes e.g., patients in hospitals, prisoners in prisons etc. Advance voting is also possible at home under specific conditions.

The concept of democracy can be associated with both public and private decision-making processes. (For example business democracies.) In Finland the highest state power is based on representative democracy in which people choose their decision-makers directly by election (for example parliamentary elections). State power also includes elements such as direct democracy, including advisory referendums.
The Real Estate Office takes care of Parliament's properties.

The Government submits to the Parliament by letter a proposal for such legislation or other act that is decided in European Union and which according to the Constitution would fall under the competence of the Parliament if Finland were not member state of EU, so as it could be defined its position. The proposition will be processed at Grand Committee where also special committees give their statements on this matter. Proposal concerning foreign affairs policy shall be handled by Foreign Affairs committee
The Information Management Office takes care of Parliament's IT services and systems.

The proposed decision in a report or statement of the committee may include one or more resolutions (resolutions). A resolution can propose e.g., approval, rejection and amendment to an act proposal as well as statements approved by parliament. In its opinion, the Constitutional Law Committee usually addresses issues related to the order for handling matters on which it has been asked to give a statement.
Genral acts include for example Administrative Procedure Act (APA), Personal Data Act and Language Act as well as the Act on Public Access to Information.

The Speaker's Council is responsible for directing parliamentary work and making proposals on the procedures to be followed in matters under consideration by Parliament. The Speaker’s Council acts as a consultative body with regard to issues within its remit, which are those of the President of the Republic or other statutes related to Parliamentary activities. It may make initiatives to Parliament concerning the Rules of Procedure for Parliament and an Act on parliamentary officials (in Finnish: laki eduskunnan virkamiehistä).
The municipal council appoints members of the central electoral committee from among those parties that have nominated candidates in previous local government elections for this municipality.

The Parliamentary Network of the World Bank is an independent organization that aims to promote transparency in particular and parliamentary debate on development cooperation issues, especially those related to the activities and practices of the World Bank. The Finnish delegation sent by Parliament for conferences organized by this network will be decided upon case-by-case basis by the Office Commission (kansliatoimikunta)
The follow-up letter will be processed like a U-letter and the Grand Committee or Foreign Affairs Committee may revise its position on it based on that.
In insurance, the President of the Republic promises to act in accordance with the Constitution and promote the success of the Finnish people.
The term of office lasts four years unless early parliamentary elections are held before that time period has passed.

The Finnish delegation consists of six actual and six alternate members who are elected by the Parliament for a parliamentary term. The delegation is led by the Speaker of the Parliament. Each year, it submits to the Parliament an annual report on its activities.

The Documents Office supplies, prints and publishes online the documents that are created during parliamentary sessions in Finland. It produces the Parliamentary Documents series as well as maintains a system for monitoring state affairs (VEPS) which is part of Parliament's information network. The office also prepares indexes based on VEPS data and statistics from it. In addition to this, the office manages an MPs' personal database and provides printing services at parliament.

In plenary session, the speech of the Speaker is interpreted into Swedish on reports made by him or her concerning proposals that have been tabled in Parliament. A summary will be provided for speeches held in Finnish and a translation may also take place privately if necessary to members who do not speak either language fluently.

The State Opening is held in Parliament's plenary hall within three days after the opening of parliament. The President of Finland gives a speech to Parliament and declares parliamentary session opened which will be followed by an answer from the Speaker of Parliament.

See the formation of government. If a candidate for prime minister does not receive more than half of all votes cast, another person is nominated as Prime Minister’s candidate. If this new nominee also fails to win over 50 per cent support in Parliament, then no nomination takes place and instead the most voted-for individual becomes Prime Minister without any nominations taking place beforehand. All voting related to choosing a prime minister are open votes (i.e., all MPs can see who has cast which vote).

The President of the Republic may order an early general election on a reasoned initiative by the Prime Minister and after consultation with political parties represented in Parliament, provided that Parliament is sitting.
Säädöksiin kuuluvat muun muassa laws and decrees, as well as legal rules issued by authorities.

A member of parliament who signs in during the roll-call at the beginning of a plenary session is considered to be present for that sitting. A representative also counts as being present if he or she registers within 15 minutes after the roll call has been completed, and thereafter when they sign-in with the Speaker (late registration).

A Member of Parliament is obliged to conduct himself in accordance with the Constitution and he cannot be bound by any instructions or orders from other authorities legally, nor can groups that elected him require his resignation during his term.
The Finnish Parliament approves or rejects a Bill in the Second Reading and informs the Government of its decision through Parliamentary Reply

A member of parliament registers as present for a plenary sitting by pressing the 'present' button. A member is considered to be present if he or she presses this button within fifteen minutes after roll-call has been taken up in the session hall.
